Question: What is an EBS (Elastic Block Store) Volume?
OptionA: A physical drive attached directly to EC2 instances
OptionB: A network drive that can be attached to EC2 instances while they run, allowing data persistence even after termination
OptionC: A global storage service accessible from anywhere
OptionD: A temporary storage that is deleted when instance stops
Explanation: An EBS Volume is a network drive you can attach to your instances while they run. It allows your instances to persist data, even after their termination. They can only be mounted to one instance at a time and are bound to a specific availability zone.

Question: What happens to an EBS volume when you move it to a different Availability Zone?
OptionA: It can be directly attached to instances in the new AZ
OptionB: You must first create a snapshot, then restore it in the new AZ
OptionC: EBS volumes can freely move between AZs without any action
OptionD: The volume is automatically replicated to all AZs
Explanation: EBS volumes are locked to an Availability Zone (AZ). An EBS Volume in us-east-1a cannot be attached to us-east-1b. To move a volume across, you first need to snapshot it, then restore the snapshot to another AZ.

Question: What is the default behavior of the root EBS volume when an EC2 instance terminates?
OptionA: It is preserved and detached
OptionB: It is deleted by default (Delete on Termination attribute enabled)
OptionC: It is automatically backed up to S3
OptionD: It remains attached to the terminated instance
Explanation: By default, the root EBS volume is deleted when an EC2 instance terminates (Delete on Termination attribute enabled). By default, any other attached EBS volume is not deleted. This can be controlled via AWS console or CLI.

Question: What are EBS Snapshots?
OptionA: Real-time backups that continuously sync data
OptionB: Point-in-time backups of EBS volumes that can be copied across AZ or Region
OptionC: Automatic backups that run every hour
OptionD: Backups stored only in the same AZ as the volume
Explanation: EBS Snapshots are backups (snapshots) of your EBS volume at a point in time. Not necessary to detach volume to do snapshot, but recommended. Can copy snapshots across AZ or Region.

Question: What is EBS Snapshot Archive?
OptionA: A feature that automatically deletes old snapshots
OptionB: A feature to move snapshots to an archive tier that is 75% cheaper, taking 24-72 hours to restore
Explanation: EBS Snapshot Archive moves a Snapshot to an archive tier that is 75% cheaper. Takes within 24 to 72 hours for restoring the archive. Useful for long-term storage of infrequently accessed snapshots.

Question: What is the Recycle Bin for EBS Snapshots?
OptionA: A feature that permanently deletes snapshots
OptionB: Setup rules to retain deleted snapshots so you can recover them after accidental deletion (retention from 1 day to 1 year)
OptionC: A feature that automatically archives old snapshots
OptionD: A feature that compresses deleted snapshots
Explanation: Recycle Bin for EBS Snapshots allows you to setup rules to retain deleted snapshots so you can recover them after an accidental deletion. Specify retention (from 1 day to 1 year).

Question: What is Fast Snapshot Restore (FSR)?
OptionA: A feature that speeds up snapshot creation
OptionB: Force full initialization of snapshot to have no latency on the first use (expensive)
OptionC: A feature that automatically restores snapshots
Explanation: Fast Snapshot Restore (FSR) forces full initialization of snapshot to have no latency on the first use. This is an expensive feature but provides instant performance when restoring volumes from snapshots.

Question: What is an AMI (Amazon Machine Image)?
OptionA: A backup of an EC2 instance
OptionB: A customization of an EC2 instance with your own software, configuration, operating system, and monitoring - faster boot time
OptionC: A network drive for EC2 instances
Explanation: AMI = Amazon Machine Image. AMIs are a customization of an EC2 instance. You add your own software, configuration, operating system, monitoring. Faster boot/configuration time because all your software is pre-packaged.

Question: What happens when you create an AMI from an EC2 instance?
OptionA: Only the instance configuration is saved
OptionB: It creates EBS snapshots of the instance's volumes
OptionD: The instance is moved to a different region
Explanation: To create an AMI: Start an EC2 instance and customize it, Stop the instance (for data integrity), Build an AMI - this will also create EBS snapshots. You can then launch instances from the AMI.

Question: What is EC2 Instance Store?
OptionA: A network-attached storage service
OptionB: High-performance hardware disk physically attached to the host - ephemeral storage that loses data when instance stops
OptionC: A backup service for EC2 instances
OptionD: A shared storage service across instances
Explanation: EC2 Instance Store provides high-performance hardware disk. Better I/O performance than EBS. EC2 Instance Store lose their storage if they're stopped (ephemeral). Good for buffer/cache/scratch data/temporary content. Risk of data loss if hardware fails.

Question: What are the EBS volume types?
OptionA: Only gp2 and io1
OptionB: gp2/gp3 (SSD General Purpose), io1/io2 Block Express (SSD Provisioned IOPS), st1 (HDD Throughput Optimized), sc1 (HDD Cold)
Explanation: EBS Volumes come in 6 types: gp2/gp3 (SSD General Purpose), io1/io2 Block Express (SSD Provisioned IOPS), st1 (HDD Throughput Optimized), sc1 (HDD Cold). Only gp2/gp3 and io1/io2 Block Express can be used as boot volumes.

Question: What are the characteristics of gp3 (General Purpose SSD) volumes?
OptionA: Same as gp2 with no improvements
OptionB: Baseline of 3,000 IOPS and throughput of 125 MiB/s, can increase IOPS up to 16,000 and throughput up to 1000 MiB/s independently
Explanation: gp3: Baseline of 3,000 IOPS and throughput of 125 MiB/s. Can increase IOPS up to 16,000 and throughput up to 1000 MiB/s independently. Cost effective storage, low-latency. Size range: 1 GiB - 16 TiB.

Question: What are the characteristics of gp2 (General Purpose SSD) volumes?
OptionA: IOPS and size are completely independent
OptionB: Small gp2 volumes can burst IOPS to 3,000. Size and IOPS are linked (3 IOPS per GB), max IOPS is 16,000 at 5,334 GB
Explanation: gp2: Small gp2 volumes can burst IOPS to 3,000. Size of the volume and IOPS are linked, max IOPS is 16,000. 3 IOPS per GB, means at 5,334 GB we are at the max IOPS. Cost effective storage, low-latency.

Question: What are Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1/io2) volumes best suited for?
OptionA: General purpose workloads
OptionB: Critical business applications with sustained IOPS performance, databases sensitive to storage performance and consistency
Explanation: Provisioned IOPS SSD volumes are for critical business applications with sustained IOPS performance, or applications that need more than 16,000 IOPS. Great for databases workloads (sensitive to storage perf and consistency).

Question: What is the maximum PIOPS for io1 volumes?
OptionA: 16,000 IOPS
OptionB: 64,000 IOPS for Nitro EC2 instances and 32,000 for other instances. Can increase PIOPS independently from storage size
Explanation: io1 (4 GiB - 16 TiB): Max PIOPS: 64,000 for Nitro EC2 instances & 32,000 for other. Can increase PIOPS independently from storage size. Great for databases workloads.

Question: What is io2 Block Express?
OptionA: A cheaper version of io1
OptionB: Sub-millisecond latency, Max PIOPS: 256,000 with an IOPS:GiB ratio of 1,000:1, supports EBS Multi-attach (4 GiB - 64 TiB)
OptionC: Same as io1 with different name
Explanation: io2 Block Express (4 GiB - 64 TiB): Sub-millisecond latency. Max PIOPS: 256,000 with an IOPS:GiB ratio of 1,000:1. Supports EBS Multi-attach. Highest performance EBS volume type.

Question: Which EBS volume types can be used as boot volumes?
OptionA: All EBS volume types
OptionB: Only gp2/gp3 and io1/io2 Block Express can be used as boot volumes
Explanation: Only gp2/gp3 and io1/io2 Block Express can be used as boot volumes. st1 and sc1 HDD volumes cannot be boot volumes.

Question: What are Throughput Optimized HDD (st1) volumes used for?
OptionA: Boot volumes and databases
OptionB: Big Data, Data Warehouses, Log Processing. Cannot be a boot volume. 125 GiB to 16 TiB
Explanation: Throughput Optimized HDD (st1): Cannot be a boot volume. 125 GiB to 16 TiB. Big Data, Data Warehouses, Log Processing. Designed for frequently accessed, throughput-intensive workloads.

Question: What are Cold HDD (sc1) volumes used for?
OptionA: Frequently accessed data
OptionB: Less frequently accessed workloads. Cannot be a boot volume. 125 GiB to 16 TiB. Lowest cost HDD volume
Explanation: Cold HDD (sc1): Cannot be a boot volume. 125 GiB to 16 TiB. Lowest cost HDD volume designed for less frequently accessed workloads.

Question: What is EBS Multi-attach?
OptionA: Attaching multiple volumes to one instance
OptionB: io1/io2 Block Express feature allowing a single EBS volume to be attached to multiple EC2 instances in the same AZ
OptionC: Attaching one volume to instances in different AZs
Explanation: EBS Multi-attach allows a single EBS volume (io1/io2 Block Express) to be attached to multiple EC2 instances in the same AZ. Useful for applications that need shared storage with high availability.

Question: What is the difference between EBS and Instance Store regarding data persistence?
OptionA: Both persist data after instance termination
OptionB: EBS persists data after instance termination, Instance Store loses data when instance stops/terminates (ephemeral)
OptionC: Both lose data when instance terminates
Explanation: EBS volumes persist data even after instance termination. EC2 Instance Store lose their storage if they're stopped (ephemeral). Instance Store is good for buffer/cache/scratch data/temporary content.

Question: What is the performance difference between EBS and Instance Store?
OptionA: EBS has higher IOPS
OptionB: Instance Store provides better I/O performance (very high IOPS) as it's physically attached to the host
OptionD: Instance Store has lower latency but EBS has higher throughput
Explanation: EBS volumes are network drives with good but limited performance. If you need high-performance hardware disk, use EC2 Instance Store. Better I/O performance. Instance Store provides very high IOPS (hundreds of thousands), very low latency, no network overhead.

Question: What is Amazon EFS (Elastic File System)?
OptionA: A block storage service like EBS
OptionB: A managed NFS (network file system) that can be mounted to multiple EC2 instances across multiple AZs. Linux only (POSIX)
Explanation: Amazon EFS is a managed file system that can be mounted to 100s of instances across AZs. EFS share website files. Only for Linux Instances (POSIX). EFS has a higher price point than EBS. Can leverage Storage Tiers for cost savings.

Question: What is the difference between EBS and EFS?
OptionA: EFS is block storage, EBS is file storage
OptionB: EBS is block storage (one instance, locked to AZ), EFS is file storage (multiple instances, multi-AZ, Linux POSIX)
OptionD: EBS is for Linux, EFS is for Windows
Explanation: EBS volumes: one instance (except multi-attach io1/io2), are locked at the Availability Zone (AZ) level. EFS: Mounting 100s of instances across AZ, EFS share website files, Only for Linux Instances (POSIX), EFS has a higher price point than EBS.

Question: What are EFS Storage Tiers?
OptionA: Only Standard tier exists
OptionB: Standard (frequently accessed), Infrequent access (EFS-IA) - cost to retrieve, lower price to store, Archive - rarely accessed data, 50% cheaper
OptionD: All tiers have the same price
Explanation: EFS Storage Tiers: Standard (for frequently accessed files), Infrequent access (EFS-IA) - cost to retrieve files, lower price to store, Archive - rarely accessed data (few times each year), 50% cheaper. Implement lifecycle policies to move files between storage tiers.

Question: What are EFS Availability modes?
OptionA: Only Multi-AZ
OptionB: Standard: Multi-AZ, great for prod. One Zone: One AZ, great for dev, backup enabled by default, compatible with IA (EFS One Zone-IA)
OptionD: Standard and One Zone are the same
Explanation: EFS Availability: Standard: Multi-AZ, great for prod. One Zone: One AZ, great for dev, backup enabled by default, compatible with IA (EFS One Zone-IA). Over 90% in cost savings with One Zone-IA.

Question: How do you migrate an EBS volume across Availability Zones?
OptionA: Directly attach it to instances in the new AZ
OptionB: Take a snapshot, then restore the snapshot to another AZ
OptionC: Copy the volume using AWS CLI
OptionD: EBS volumes cannot be moved across AZs
Explanation: EBS volumes are locked to an Availability Zone (AZ). An EBS Volume in us-east-1a cannot be attached to us-east-1b. To migrate an EBS volume across AZ: Take a snapshot, Restore the snapshot to another AZ.

Question: What should you consider when taking EBS snapshots?
OptionA: Snapshots can only be taken when instance is stopped
OptionB: Not necessary to detach volume to do snapshot, but recommended. EBS backups use IO and you shouldn't run them while your application is handling a lot of traffic
OptionD: Snapshots can only be taken once per day
Explanation: EBS Snapshots: Not necessary to detach volume to do snapshot, but recommended. Can copy snapshots across AZ or Region. EBS backups use IO and you shouldn't run them while your application is handling a lot of traffic.

Question: What happens to EBS volumes when an EC2 instance is terminated?
OptionA: All volumes are always preserved
OptionB: Root EBS volumes get terminated by default if the EC2 instance gets terminated (you can disable that). Other attached volumes are preserved by default
OptionD: Volumes are automatically backed up to S3
Explanation: Root EBS Volumes of instances get terminated by default if the EC2 instance gets terminated (you can disable that). By default, any other attached EBS volume is not deleted (attribute disabled). This can be controlled by the AWS console / AWS CLI.

Question: What is the relationship between EBS volume size and IOPS for gp2 volumes?
OptionA: IOPS and size are completely independent
OptionB: Size of the volume and IOPS are linked - 3 IOPS per GB, max IOPS is 16,000 at 5,334 GB
OptionC: IOPS is fixed at 3,000 regardless of size
OptionD: Larger volumes always have lower IOPS
Explanation: For gp2 volumes: Size of the volume and IOPS are linked, max IOPS is 16,000. 3 IOPS per GB, means at 5,334 GB we are at the max IOPS. Small gp2 volumes can burst IOPS to 3,000.

Question: What is the relationship between EBS volume size and IOPS for gp3 and io1/io2 volumes?
OptionA: IOPS and size are always linked
OptionB: gp3 & io1/io2: can increase IOPS independently from storage size
Explanation: For gp3 & io1/io2: can increase IOPS independently. gp2: IO increases if the disk size increases. gp3: Baseline of 3,000 IOPS, can increase up to 16,000 independently. io1/io2: Can increase PIOPS independently from storage size.
